clinical_note: Susan Green is a 6-year-old girl with a history notable for recurrent episodes concerning for seizures, characterized by sudden unresponsiveness and generalized stiffening followed by rhythmic jerking movements, with postictal confusion and fatigue. Events have occurred without clear triggers and have required emergency evaluation on multiple occasions. Clinical concerns also include persistently abnormal laboratory studies, with intermittently elevated liver transaminases and lactate, raising suspicion for an underlying metabolic disorder contributing to her neurologic symptoms. Parents report no clear developmental regression, but they have noticed increased clumsiness and occasional difficulty with balance following these episodes. There is a family history of a paternal uncle with epilepsy beginning in adolescence, as well as a maternal grandfather with type 2 diabetes and hypertension. No consanguinity is reported. Prior evaluation has included routine blood work and brain imaging; neuroimaging has reportedly been unremarkable, while metabolic screening has shown mild, nonspecific abnormalities that have prompted referral for further genetic and metabolic assessment.

Brian Hill is a young infant with a history notable for poor feeding, intermittent vomiting, and difficulty gaining weight despite adequate caloric intake. Parents report episodes of lethargy and irritability, particularly during minor illnesses or prolonged fasting, raising concern for an underlying disturbance of intermediary metabolism. Laboratory evaluations from the referring provider reportedly showed nonspecific abnormalities suggestive of a metabolic disorder affecting cellular energy handling, and further workup is in progress. Neurologically, caregivers have noticed that Brian appears “wobbly” when attempting supported sitting and has poorly coordinated limb movements for age. Examination today is notable for truncal instability and impaired coordination of purposeful reaching, consistent with early cerebellar ataxia, though muscle tone and strength are otherwise grossly appropriate for age. Developmental milestones are otherwise loosely on track. Family history is significant for a maternal uncle with progressive gait imbalance and frequent falls beginning in adolescence, as well as a paternal cousin who required evaluation for an unexplained metabolic condition in early childhood.

James Adams is a 13-year-old boy with a history notable for intermittent neurological symptoms and persistent laboratory abnormalities. Over the past several years, his parents have observed episodes of unsteadiness and clumsiness, particularly when he is fatigued, with a broad-based, wavering gait and difficulty with coordinated fine motor tasks such as handwriting and buttoning clothes. Teachers report that he occasionally appears shaky when reaching for objects and has trouble with rapid alternating movements during school-based motor assessments. Clinical concerns also include chronically abnormal blood test results of unclear significance, with repeatedly documented elevations outside the reference range prompting evaluation for an underlying metabolic or systemic disorder. There is no history of acute intoxication, trauma, or major systemic illness to account for these findings. Family history is notable for a maternal uncle with “poor balance” beginning in mid-adulthood, requiring use of a cane in his 50s, though he has never received a specific diagnosis. No other relatives are known to have similar neurologic or unexplained biochemical abnormalities.

Mark Baker (born 2012-09-08) is an intersex child presenting for evaluation of recurrent neurologic events and a suspected underlying metabolic disorder. History is notable for intermittent episodes characterized by sudden loss of responsiveness with generalized shaking, followed by postictal confusion and fatigue; these spells have occurred without clear provocation and have raised concern for unprovoked seizures. Parents also report intermittent vomiting, poor exercise tolerance, and episodic lethargy, sometimes associated with minor illnesses or prolonged fasting, suggesting possible disturbances in intermediary metabolism. Growth and school performance are described as generally appropriate, though he occasionally misses school due to these events and subsequent fatigue. There is no known exposure to neurotoxic medications or substances. Family history is notable for a paternal uncle with childhood-onset seizure disorder of unclear etiology and a maternal cousin reported to have a “metabolic problem” requiring dietary restriction, though specific diagnosis is unknown. No prior genetic testing has been documented. Mark currently remains under evaluation for an underlying neurometabolic cause contributing to his seizure-like episodes.

Mark Young is a 9-year-old intersex patient with a history notable for recurrent unexplained seizures beginning in early childhood. Events are described as sudden episodes of unresponsiveness with generalized tonic stiffening and occasional rhythmic jerking, followed by postictal confusion and fatigue. Seizure frequency has been variable, with several prolonged events requiring emergency evaluation; no clear provoking factors have been identified. Clinical concerns also include persistently abnormal laboratory findings on multiple assessments, with intermittent elevations in serum markers suggestive of an underlying metabolic disturbance; these abnormalities have not yet been fully characterized and appear disproportionate to intercurrent illness. Family history is significant for a maternal uncle with childhood-onset epilepsy that improved in adolescence, and a paternal cousin reportedly evaluated for an unspecified metabolic disorder in infancy. There is no known history of sudden unexplained death in the family. Mark is currently under the care of neurology and metabolic specialists, and further diagnostic workup is ongoing to clarify the etiology of the seizure disorder and biochemical abnormalities.

Dorothy Young is a 2½‑year‑old girl with a history notable for difficulties tolerating dairy products and concerns regarding coordination. Since early childhood, parents have observed that ingestion of cow’s milk and ice cream leads to abdominal cramping, bloating, and loose stools, prompting a largely dairy-free diet with partial improvement in symptoms. Growth has remained appropriate, though there is concern about limited calcium intake. Neurologically, caregivers report an unsteady, wide-based gait and frequent falls, particularly when she is tired or walking on uneven surfaces. On examination, she demonstrates mild truncal instability and intention tremor when reaching for objects, with otherwise normal strength and tone. Language and social development are age appropriate. There is no history of seizures or regression. Family history is notable for a maternal uncle described as “clumsy” since childhood with lifelong balance difficulties, and a paternal grandmother with longstanding intolerance to milk products requiring dietary restriction. No prior genetic or metabolic testing has been documented.

Nancy Smith is a 2-year-old girl with a history notable for recurrent episodes concerning for seizures and persistently abnormal laboratory studies suggestive of an underlying metabolic disturbance. Since late infancy, parents have observed intermittent spells characterized by brief unresponsiveness and generalized stiffening, sometimes followed by postictal sleepiness; no clear triggers have been identified. She has had at least two emergency evaluations for these events, during which routine labs repeatedly demonstrated unexplained abnormalities in metabolic parameters, prompting referral for further evaluation. Development has otherwise been reported as age-appropriate, with no regression, and growth has tracked along expected percentiles. Pregnancy and delivery were reportedly uncomplicated. There is no known exposure to toxins, medications, or significant perinatal insults. Family history is notable for a maternal uncle with childhood-onset seizure episodes that resolved in adolescence, and a paternal cousin reported to have “low energy” and difficulty tolerating fasting, though no formal diagnosis is known. No other relatives are known to have neurologic or metabolic conditions, and there is no reported consanguinity.

William Lewis (born 2005-07-15) is seen for ongoing management of neurologic and metabolic concerns. History is notable for recurrent unprovoked seizures beginning in later childhood, with episodes characterized by loss of awareness and bilateral motor involvement, sometimes clustering over several days and requiring emergency care. Seizure control has been difficult, with periods of incomplete response to antiseizure medications and occasional breakthrough events without clear triggers. In addition, he has long‑standing intolerance to dairy products, with abdominal cramping, bloating, and loose stools following ingestion of milk or ice cream, leading the family to restrict lactose-containing foods and use lactase supplements with partial benefit. Growth and school performance have otherwise been reported as appropriate. Family history is significant for a younger sister with childhood-onset generalized epilepsy that is currently well controlled on medication, and a maternal uncle with “severe milk intolerance” who avoids all dairy. There is no known consanguinity. No prior genetic testing has been documented.

Thomas Davis (born 2012-04-29) is an intersex child referred for ongoing evaluation of episodic neurologic events and metabolic instability. History is notable for recurrent generalized seizures without clear focal onset, occurring both during wakefulness and sleep, with several episodes progressing to status requiring emergency intervention. Seizures have been variably triggered by intercurrent illness and periods of poor oral intake. Between events, caregivers report intermittent fatigue and decreased exercise tolerance but no persistent focal deficits. Clinical concerns include recurrent disturbances in acid–base balance, with documented episodes of significant metabolic acidosis characterized by low serum bicarbonate and compensatory hyperventilation, occasionally associated with vomiting and dehydration. These metabolic crises have required intravenous fluids and close monitoring, though Thomas typically returns to baseline between episodes. Development and school performance are described as appropriate for age, with no regression reported. Family history is notable for a paternal uncle with childhood-onset epilepsy that improved in adolescence, and a maternal grandmother with “weak spells” during illnesses, though she was never formally evaluated by a metabolic specialist.

Paul Scott (born 2010-08-18, intersex) is seen for ongoing neurologic and metabolic concerns. History is notable for chronic issues with balance and coordination, described by caregivers as frequent stumbling, difficulty with tandem gait, and clumsiness during fine motor tasks such as handwriting and buttoning clothes. On examination, he shows an ataxic gait with impaired finger-to-nose testing and mild dysmetria, more pronounced with eyes closed, raising concern for a cerebellar process. Clinical concerns also include persistently abnormal laboratory findings suggestive of a metabolic disturbance, with repeatedly elevated unspecified serum markers on prior evaluations, though without a definitive biochemical diagnosis to date. Family history is positive for a maternal uncle with long-standing gait instability and progressive coordination difficulties beginning in adolescence, as well as a paternal grandmother with “unexplained liver problems” and intermittent fatigue in mid-life. No known consanguinity is reported. Paul continues to attend school with some accommodations for motor tasks and fatigue, and further metabolic and neurologic workup is planned.

Mark Hill is a 14-year-old intersex individual referred for evaluation of recurrent neurological events and abnormal laboratory findings. History is notable for several episodes characterized by sudden loss of responsiveness with generalized stiffening and rhythmic jerking, followed by postictal confusion and fatigue; events have occurred without clear provoking factors and have led to emergency evaluations. Caregivers describe intermittent headaches and occasional transient visual blurring, though no persistent focal deficits have been documented. Clinical concerns also include persistently abnormal serum biochemical values on prior testing, with fluctuating elevations suggestive of an underlying metabolic disturbance; no clear dietary trigger has been identified, and growth and school performance have been generally appropriate for age. Family history is significant for a maternal uncle with childhood-onset seizures that improved with medication, and a paternal cousin reportedly evaluated for “abnormal liver tests” in adolescence, though details are limited. No known consanguinity is reported. Mark currently follows with neurology and metabolic specialists, and further genetic evaluation is being pursued to clarify an underlying etiology.

Nancy Lee is a 12-year-old girl with a history notable for recurrent unprovoked seizures beginning in early childhood. Events are described as sudden staring with unresponsiveness followed at times by generalized tonic-clonic activity, tongue biting, and postictal confusion. Seizures have occurred both during sleep and wakefulness, with no consistent triggers identified. She is currently followed by neurology and treated with antiseizure medication, with partial reduction in event frequency but no complete remission. Interictal periods are generally well, though parents report intermittent fatigue and mild headaches. Recent laboratory evaluation has shown persistently abnormal serum markers suggestive of an underlying metabolic disturbance, prompting further workup to assess for an inborn error of metabolism or other systemic cause contributing to her seizure susceptibility. Family history is notable for a maternal uncle with childhood-onset epilepsy that resolved in adolescence, and a paternal grandmother with type 2 diabetes and hyperlipidemia. There is no known history of sudden unexplained death in the family.

Charles Davis is a 11-year-old boy with a history notable for recurrent unprovoked seizures beginning in early childhood, currently characterized by focal impaired-awareness events with occasional secondary generalization. Seizures are described as brief staring spells with behavioral arrest and automatisms, followed by confusion and fatigue; more prolonged convulsive episodes have required emergency evaluation on several occasions. He is treated with antiseizure medication with only partial control, and there is concern for ongoing subclinical events affecting school performance and attention. Clinical concerns also include longstanding difficulty tolerating dairy products, with abdominal cramping, bloating, and loose stools after ingestion of milk or ice cream, leading the family to largely restrict lactose-containing foods; symptoms improve with avoidance and over-the-counter lactase supplementation. Family history is notable for a maternal uncle with childhood-onset epilepsy that persists into adulthood, treated with multiple antiseizure agents, and a paternal grandmother with type 2 diabetes and hypertension. There is no known history of similar gastrointestinal intolerance in first-degree relatives.

Daniel Jones (born 27-Mar-2021, intersex) is seen for ongoing neurologic and metabolic concerns. History is notable for recurrent unprovoked seizures beginning in early childhood, with episodes characterized by loss of awareness, generalized tonic stiffening, and subsequent confusion. Events occur without clear triggers and have required emergency evaluation on several occasions. Parents report intermittent clustering of seizures despite adherence to prescribed antiseizure medications, and there is concern for incomplete control. Developmental progress has otherwise been largely age-appropriate per parental report. Clinical concerns also include lifelong intolerance to dairy products; even small amounts of milk or ice cream lead to abdominal cramping, bloating, and loose stools, prompting the family to restrict lactose-containing foods. Family history is significant for a paternal uncle with epilepsy diagnosed in adolescence and currently treated with medication, and a maternal grandmother with “severe milk intolerance” who avoids most dairy. No prior genetic testing has been performed for Daniel or affected relatives.

Robert Martinez, born 23 Feb 2011, is seen for ongoing neurologic and metabolic concerns. Since early childhood, he has exhibited marked unsteadiness of gait with difficulty coordinating voluntary movements, particularly when reaching for objects or navigating uneven surfaces. Parents report frequent falls, clumsiness in fine motor tasks such as buttoning and handwriting, and a wide-based gait that has become more apparent with age. Teachers note that he tires easily during physical activities and has trouble with tasks requiring precise hand–eye coordination. Clinical concerns also include a history of abnormal amino acid metabolism, with prior evaluations indicating a defect in phenylalanine processing; dietary protein restriction and specialized medical formula have been intermittently implemented, with variable adherence. Family history is notable for a maternal uncle with a lifelong tremor and balance difficulties requiring use of a cane in mid-adulthood, and a paternal cousin with learning challenges of unclear etiology. No other known neurologic or metabolic conditions are reported in close relatives.

Daniel Martin is a 14-year-old male with a history notable for intermittent episodes of metabolic decompensation characterized by fatigue, poor exercise tolerance, and intermittent vomiting during minor illnesses. Parents report that since early childhood he has had difficulty maintaining weight during periods of stress or infection, with occasional need for urgent evaluation due to dehydration and laboratory evidence of metabolic imbalance. Between episodes he is generally well, though he continues to exhibit reduced stamina compared with peers. Neurologically, his course has been marked by intermittent generalized hypotonia, more pronounced during acute metabolic stress, with delayed achievement of some gross motor milestones in early childhood but eventual independent ambulation. There is no history of seizures, focal weakness, or regression of skills. Family history is significant for a younger maternal cousin with unexplained episodes of “low blood sugar” requiring hospitalizations in early childhood, as well as a paternal uncle with chronic muscle weakness of unclear etiology. No consanguinity is reported. Daniel currently attends school with some accommodations during periods of illness-related fatigue.

David Moore is a 15-year-old male with a history notable for recurrent metabolic decompensations characterized by episodes of metabolic acidosis, often triggered by minor intercurrent illnesses. Parents report intermittent tachypnea, lethargy, and poor oral intake during these episodes, with laboratory evaluations repeatedly demonstrating low serum bicarbonate and elevated anion gap, requiring intravenous fluids and close monitoring. Since early childhood, he has also exhibited intermittent neuromuscular irritability, with periods of increased tone and occasional jitteriness, more prominent during febrile illnesses or metabolic stress. There is no history of seizures, but caregivers describe brief episodes of stiffening and tremulousness that resolve spontaneously. Developmental milestones have otherwise been appropriate for age. Family history is notable for a younger sister who experienced transient neonatal jitteriness that resolved without sequelae, and a maternal uncle with a history of “acid-base problems” during hospitalizations for severe vomiting in adolescence, though no definitive diagnosis was established. No known consanguinity is reported.

Nancy Rivera is a 15-year-old girl with a history notable for recurrent generalized seizures beginning in later childhood, without a clearly identified provoking factor. Events are described as sudden loss of awareness with tonic–clonic movements, postictal confusion, and occasional tongue biting; there is no consistent aura reported. She has required multiple emergency visits for prolonged seizures and has been treated acutely with benzodiazepines. Interictal periods are generally well, though her parents note increasing fatigue and intermittent headaches following clusters of events. Clinical concerns also include recurrent metabolic derangements, particularly episodes of acidosis documented during acute illnesses and after more severe seizures, with low serum bicarbonate and elevated anion gap, improving with intravenous fluids and correction of underlying stressors. There is no known exposure to toxins or drugs that would explain these findings. Family history is notable for a younger brother with febrile seizures in early childhood and a maternal uncle reported to have “epilepsy” requiring long-term antiseizure medication. No prior genetic testing has been documented to date.

Karen Young is a 16-year-old female with a history notable for recurrent generalized seizures beginning in mid-childhood, described as sudden loss of consciousness with tonic–clonic activity and prolonged postictal confusion. Events have occurred both during wakefulness and sleep, with several episodes requiring emergency department evaluation and one prior hospitalization for status epilepticus. She is currently treated with antiseizure medication, though adherence has been inconsistent per parental report, and breakthrough seizures persist. Clinical course has been complicated by intermittent metabolic derangements during acute episodes, including documented low serum bicarbonate with high anion gap and transient tachypnea, attributed to lactic acidosis in the setting of prolonged seizures and reduced perfusion. Between episodes she returns to baseline functioning without persistent focal deficits. Family history is notable for a younger brother with childhood-onset epilepsy now well controlled on medication, and a maternal uncle who reportedly had “fits” as a teenager but was never formally evaluated. There is no known history of neuromuscular disease or inborn errors of metabolism in the family.

Mark Martin is a young intersex child with clinical concerns centered on neurological and metabolic features. Since early infancy, caregivers have noted intermittent unsteadiness and poor coordination, described as difficulty maintaining balance and a clumsy, wide-based gait, with occasional intention tremor when reaching for objects. Feeding history is notable for irritability, abdominal bloating, and loose stools following ingestion of milk and other dairy products, with improvement when lactose-containing foods are limited, raising concern for a primary disorder of lactose digestion. Growth has been appropriate, though there is vigilance around nutritional adequacy given dietary restrictions. Developmental progress otherwise appears age-appropriate, with no reported regression or loss of skills. Family history is significant for a maternal uncle with long-standing gait imbalance attributed to a cerebellar process, and a maternal grandmother who has chronic digestive difficulties requiring avoidance of dairy products. No known consanguinity is reported. Further evaluation is aimed at clarifying the etiology of the coordination difficulties and confirming a suspected lactose intolerance while supporting optimal growth and neurologic function.

Timothy Martin is a 2½‑year‑old intersex child with a history notable for early global developmental concerns and multiple congenital anomalies. Since infancy, parents have reported delayed attainment of motor and language milestones, with persistent difficulties in attention and concentration during structured activities. Physical examination documents distinctive craniofacial features consistent with a recognizable pattern of congenital malformation, along with external ear anomalies including abnormal positioning and shape. Neuroimaging has demonstrated underdevelopment of the cerebral hemispheres, contributing to his developmental profile. Cardiac evaluation identified a defect involving the atrial septum, for which he is under ongoing cardiology follow‑up. Overall appearance and growth pattern raise concern for an underlying syndromic condition affecting multiple organ systems. Prior genetic evaluation with a single‑gene assay was nondiagnostic, with negative results reported. Timothy continues to receive developmental therapies and multidisciplinary care, and further comprehensive genetic testing is being pursued to clarify the etiology and guide prognosis and management.

Michelle Wright is a 10-year-old girl with a history notable for significant developmental impairment, functioning in the severe range with limited expressive language and dependence for most activities of daily living. Since early childhood, caregivers have observed unusual facial and craniofacial features, including asymmetry of the external ears and a generally disproportionate facial appearance, prompting evaluation for an underlying syndromic diagnosis. She also carries a diagnosis of complex congenital heart disease, including a defect in the tissue separating the upper heart chambers and malformation of the outflow tract from the right ventricle, for which she has undergone cardiology follow-up and prior surgical assessment. Growth and development have remained globally delayed, with persistent challenges in fine and gross motor skills and learning. Physical examination is remarkable for multiple congenital anomalies and a pattern of dysmorphic features consistent with a recognizable congenital syndrome. Prior genetic testing with chromosomal microarray analysis was nondiagnostic (reported as negative), and she is now referred for further genomic evaluation to clarify an underlying etiology and guide management.

Daniel Gonzalez is a school‑aged child with a history notable for global developmental delay in the moderate range, with significant limitations in academic skills and adaptive functioning. Since early childhood, caregivers have observed delayed language acquisition and need for ongoing support with daily living skills. Birth and early growth were complicated by multiple structural anomalies, including congenital deformity of the feet consistent with clubfoot‑type positioning and abnormal shaping of the skull and facial structures, with persistent craniofacial asymmetry and characteristic facial features on examination. Cardiac history is significant for a congenital malformation of the outflow tract involving the pulmonary valve region, followed by pediatric cardiology with prior interventions discussed in the chart. Overall appearance and pattern of congenital findings raise concern for an underlying syndromic etiology affecting growth and craniofacial development. Prior genetic evaluation included a targeted gene panel, which was reported as negative, without identification of a causative variant. Daniel continues to receive multidisciplinary care, including developmental, orthopedic, and cardiology follow‑up.

Joshua Garcia is a 18-year-old male with a longstanding history of global developmental delay and moderate intellectual disability, first recognized in early childhood when he missed major motor and language milestones. He continues to require support for activities of daily living and structured educational services. Since infancy, his head shape has been described as abnormal, with a congenitally small head circumference and persistent microcephaly. Physical examination has repeatedly noted multiple minor anomalies and a pattern of dysmorphic features consistent with an underlying congenital syndrome, including abnormal craniofacial proportions and atypical skull contour suggestive of a primary brain malformation. Clinical concerns include difficulties with adaptive functioning, limited expressive language, and concrete reasoning skills, though behavior has been generally cooperative without significant psychiatric comorbidity. There is no known family history of similar neurodevelopmental or congenital findings. Prior genetic evaluation included single-gene testing targeting a suspected syndrome, which was negative, and he is now referred for broader genetic assessment to better define an etiologic diagnosis and guide anticipatory management and counseling.

Christopher Hill is a 10-year-old intersex child with a history notable for multiple congenital anomalies and intellectual disability. Since infancy, he has had distinctive craniofacial features, including abnormal ear shape and position, contributing to an overall dysmorphic appearance. Cardiac evaluation in early childhood identified a congenital abnormality of the outflow tract, and he has been followed by cardiology for surveillance and management. Renal imaging has shown structural kidney anomalies consistent with cystic changes and maldevelopment, requiring ongoing nephrology monitoring for blood pressure and renal function. Developmentally, Christopher demonstrates moderate intellectual disability, with significant delays in academic skills and adaptive functioning; he requires specialized educational support and assistance with daily living tasks. Growth parameters and body proportions have raised concern for an underlying congenital malformation syndrome affecting multiple organ systems. Prior genetic testing with chromosomal microarray analysis was nondiagnostic. He is referred today for further genetic evaluation to clarify an underlying syndromic diagnosis, guide anticipatory management, and provide counseling to the family regarding prognosis and recurrence risk.

Karen Wright is a 9-year-old girl with a history notable for abnormal neuromuscular tone in the neonatal period, described as generalized hypotonia with poor head control and delayed attainment of early motor milestones. Parents recall that as an infant she tired easily with feeding and appeared “floppy,” though cognition and social interaction have remained age appropriate. Over time she has continued to demonstrate low muscle tone and reduced endurance, with difficulty keeping up with peers in physical activities and occasional complaints of leg fatigue after minimal exertion. Clinical concerns also include features suggestive of an underlying metabolic disturbance affecting energy utilization, with intermittent episodes of worsened fatigue during intercurrent illness and mild weight fluctuations despite stable dietary intake. There is no history of seizures or regression. Family history is notable for a maternal uncle with lifelong muscle weakness requiring the use of a cane in adulthood, and a paternal grandmother with type 2 diabetes and hyperlipidemia. No known consanguinity is reported.

Donna Anderson is a 7-year-old girl with a history notable for episodic metabolic instability characterized by recurrent episodes of metabolic acidosis, often precipitated by intercurrent illness and decreased oral intake. Parents describe periods of lethargy, poor feeding, and tachypnea during these events, with laboratory evaluations repeatedly demonstrating low serum bicarbonate and an elevated anion gap, requiring IV fluids and close metabolic monitoring. Since the neonatal period, she has also exhibited increased neuromuscular irritability, including intermittent hypertonia and jitteriness, which were initially most prominent in the first months of life and have persisted as mild stiffness and exaggerated startle. Developmental progress has otherwise been age-appropriate per parental report. There is a positive family history: a maternal uncle with a seizure disorder beginning in childhood and a paternal grandmother with type 2 diabetes and hypertension. No known consanguinity is reported. Donna currently follows with pediatric neurology and metabolic specialists, and her parents are seeking further evaluation to clarify the underlying etiology and guide long-term management.

Anthony Hill, born 2022-04-02, is referred for evaluation of episodic neurologic events and persistent laboratory abnormalities. Since late infancy, caregivers have reported recurrent episodes characterized by generalized stiffening and unresponsiveness, occasionally followed by post-event somnolence; these events have occurred without clear provocation or fever. Clinical concerns also include repeatedly documented abnormal serum laboratory values suggestive of an underlying metabolic disturbance, though specific etiology remains unclear. Between episodes, development has been generally age-appropriate per parental report, and there are no consistent focal neurologic deficits observed. Family history is notable for a maternal uncle with a history of childhood-onset seizures that reportedly resolved in adolescence without identified cause. A paternal grandmother is known to have type 2 diabetes and hyperlipidemia, and a maternal grandfather has a history of ischemic heart disease requiring stent placement in his 50s. No known consanguinity is reported. Further neurologic and metabolic workup, including genetic evaluation, is being pursued to clarify the underlying diagnosis and guide management.

Andrew Torres is a 19-year-old male with a history notable for recurrent focal seizures beginning in later childhood, now characterized by impaired awareness and occasional secondary generalization. Seizure frequency has fluctuated despite multiple antiepileptic medications, with recent episodes including brief behavioral arrest, oral automatisms, and postictal confusion. Parents also report intermittent episodes of lightheadedness and fatigue associated with nonspecific laboratory abnormalities on prior metabolic and biochemical evaluations, though no unifying diagnosis has been established. There is no history of developmental delay or regression. Birth and early childhood were reportedly unremarkable. Neurological examinations between episodes have been largely nonfocal, though he describes occasional tension-type headaches and difficulty with sustained concentration, particularly following clusters of seizures. Family history is significant for a younger sister with childhood-onset epilepsy now well controlled on monotherapy, and a maternal uncle with “low blood counts” and unexplained episodes of weakness requiring hospital evaluation. No known hereditary diagnosis has been documented in the family to date.

Donna Sanchez is a 13-year-old girl with a history notable for recurrent unprovoked seizures beginning in mid-childhood, now characterized by focal-onset events with impaired awareness and secondary generalization. Episodes are described as brief staring spells followed by right arm stiffening and occasional progression to bilateral tonic-clonic activity, with postictal confusion and fatigue. Seizures occur despite adherence to antiseizure medication, and there is concern for incomplete control. Intermittent laboratory evaluations have shown persistently abnormal serum biochemical markers, including fluctuating transaminase elevations and occasional mild lactic acidosis, raising suspicion for an underlying metabolic vulnerability contributing to her neurologic presentation. Development and school performance are otherwise age-appropriate, though parents report increased fatigue on days following seizure clusters. Family history is notable for a maternal uncle with childhood-onset epilepsy requiring long-term medication, as well as a paternal grandmother with type 2 diabetes and hyperlipidemia. There is no known consanguinity, and no relatives with documented metabolic disorders, stroke at a young age, or progressive neurodegenerative disease.

Sharon Walker is a 18-year-old female with a history notable for recurrent episodes of metabolic acidosis, often presenting with fatigue, tachypnea, and malaise during intercurrent illnesses. Parents report several emergency visits over the past few years for low serum bicarbonate and elevated anion gap, improving with IV fluids and careful metabolic management. Neurologically, she has persistent gait unsteadiness and impaired coordination, described as clumsiness since late childhood, with difficulty on tandem walking and fine motor tasks such as handwriting and buttoning. She sustained a right ankle sprain while playing sports and more recently experienced a mild closed head injury without loss of consciousness; since then, she notes intermittent headaches but no focal deficits. Family history is notable for a younger brother with similar “balance problems” and frequent falls, currently under evaluation by neurology. A maternal uncle reportedly had unexplained episodes of “acid in the blood” requiring hospitalizations in adolescence. No known parental consanguinity.

Daniel Torres is a 3-year-old boy with a history notable for recurrent episodes of transient unresponsiveness and generalized shaking concerning for seizures, without a clearly identified precipitant. Parents report postictal confusion and fatigue, with several events associated with poor oral intake and intercurrent illness. During one such episode, laboratory evaluation revealed a significant metabolic acidosis, prompting concern for an underlying metabolic vulnerability in the setting of acute stress or dehydration. Clinical course is further complicated by a prior mild head injury with brief loss of consciousness after a fall, described as a concussion, from which he recovered without persistent focal deficits. Earlier in childhood he sustained a forehead laceration requiring repair but without skull fracture. Medication history includes prior exposure to penicillin, after which he developed symptoms consistent with a toxic reaction rather than classic allergy. Family history is notable for a paternal uncle with childhood-onset seizures that resolved in adolescence and a maternal cousin with recurrent fainting spells of unclear etiology.

Thomas Moore is a young intersex child with a history notable for recurrent seizure-like episodes beginning in early childhood, described as generalized convulsions with postictal lethargy and no clear provoking factors. Caregivers report intermittent episodes of unexplained fatigue and poor tolerance of fasting, raising concern for an underlying disturbance of metabolic homeostasis; prior evaluations have suggested a possible disorder of intermediary metabolism, though a specific diagnosis has not yet been established. Clinical course has also been complicated by a prior superficial burn injury to the face requiring acute care, as well as a scalp laceration from minor head trauma that healed without neurologic sequelae. Family history is significant for a maternal uncle with childhood-onset epilepsy and a paternal cousin with an unspecified inborn error of metabolism requiring dietary management. Additional family history includes a father with early-onset hypertension and a maternal grandmother with type 2 diabetes. No known consanguinity is reported.

Dorothy Torres is a 3-year-old girl with a history notable for feeding intolerance to cow’s milk since infancy, characterized by bloating, diarrhea, and poor weight gain that improved with lactose-free formulations. Clinical concerns also include intermittent neuromuscular irritability in the neonatal period, with episodes of increased tone and jitteriness noted shortly after birth, gradually improving but prompting ongoing developmental surveillance. Parents report a prior hospitalization in early infancy for evaluation of unusual movements and irritability, during which metabolic workup suggested vulnerability to nutritional and electrolyte shifts, and she has since been monitored for metabolic stability during intercurrent illnesses. There is a history of an accidental exposure to a penicillin-class antibiotic resulting in acute gastrointestinal distress and rash, leading to its avoidance thereafter. Earlier in life she sustained a superficial facial burn from a hot liquid, which healed without complication but is documented in her medical record. Family history is notable for a maternal uncle with “muscle stiffness” in childhood and a paternal grandmother with adult-onset type 2 diabetes.

Kevin Mitchell is a 15-year-old male with a history notable for intermittent unsteadiness and difficulty with coordination over the past several years. Parents describe episodes of clumsiness, a wide-based gait at times, and trouble with fine motor tasks such as handwriting and buttoning clothes, which have become more apparent with increased academic demands. Clinical concerns also include persistently abnormal laboratory findings on prior metabolic evaluations, with unexplained elevations prompting ongoing assessment for an underlying metabolic or systemic disorder. There is no clear history of regression, but fatigue and exercise intolerance are intermittently reported. Kevin was previously treated in the emergency department for a superficial forehead laceration after a minor fall and, on a separate occasion, sustained a superficial facial burn from accidental contact with a hot surface; both injuries healed without complication but raised additional concern about balance and safety. Family history is notable for a maternal uncle with longstanding coordination problems requiring use of a cane in adulthood, and a maternal grandfather reported to have “abnormal blood tests” of unclear etiology.

Joshua Flores (born 2015-01-08) is a school-aged child presenting today for follow-up after multiple recent injuries. History is notable for a superficial burn to the face involving unspecified degree, sustained when he accidentally contacted a hot surface in the kitchen; there was no reported inhalation injury, and the area has been healing with topical care. More recently, he twisted his right ankle while playing sports, resulting in pain, swelling, and difficulty bearing weight; examination at the time was consistent with a moderate sprain without gross instability. Additionally, he experienced a brief head injury after a fall from standing height, with transient headache but no loss of consciousness, vomiting, or focal neurological deficits. Initial evaluation in the emergency setting documented a mild closed head trauma without evidence of intracranial hemorrhage, and symptoms have since improved. At today’s visit, Joshua appears comfortable and interactive, with healing facial skin changes, resolving right ankle tenderness, and no current neurological complaints. Ongoing management focuses on injury prevention, safe activity resumption, and monitoring for any delayed post-concussive symptoms.

Jessica Scott is a 14-year-old girl seen following an acute medication-related event and recent head trauma. History is notable for accidental ingestion of a penicillin-class antibiotic at home, after which she developed symptoms concerning enough to prompt emergency evaluation and treatment for suspected drug toxicity. Around the same time period, she sustained a minor closed head injury without documented loss of consciousness after striking her head during a fall. Initial assessment described transient headache and brief confusion, but no persistent neurologic deficits. Examination in follow-up has focused on monitoring for any evolving post-concussive symptoms, including changes in cognition, mood, or school performance, none of which have been clearly reported to date. Records also document a superficial laceration of the scalp in the frontal region, which was cleaned and repaired in the emergency department without complication. At today’s visit, the emphasis is on ensuring complete recovery from the head injury, reviewing medication safety to prevent further accidental exposures, and confirming that no delayed complications have arisen.

John Harris (born 2015-04-03) is a school-aged child presenting today for follow-up after an acute head injury sustained in a recent accident. History is notable for a brief loss of consciousness at the scene, with subsequent evaluation in the emergency department. Since the event, caregivers report intermittent headaches and mild difficulty concentrating, though there have been no witnessed seizures or persistent vomiting. Physical examination at the time of injury documented a superficial facial and scalp burn involving the forehead and upper scalp region, without apparent deeper tissue involvement. Initial management included wound cleansing and topical care, and the burns are now healing with minimal scarring. Medication history is significant for recent exposure to a penicillin-class antibiotic prior to presentation, after which the patient developed diffuse pruritus and urticarial rash, raising concern for a drug-related toxic reaction; the antibiotic was discontinued with gradual resolution of symptoms. There is no reported family history of similar neurologic injuries, burn incidents, or severe medication reactions.

Steven King is a 5-year-old boy brought for evaluation following an acute injury. History is notable for a recent head trauma with brief loss of consciousness; since the event, caregivers report transient confusion but no persistent focal neurologic deficits. He was initially assessed in the emergency setting, where imaging reportedly showed no intracranial hemorrhage, and he has been recovering at home with gradual improvement in alertness and behavior. The same incident also resulted in superficial thermal injury to the scalp and upper face, described as involving the epidermis without blistering or deep tissue damage; these areas have been managed with local wound care and appear to be healing appropriately. In addition, there is documentation of an adverse reaction temporally associated with administration of a penicillin-class antibiotic, characterized by acute onset of rash and pruritus shortly after dosing; no respiratory compromise or hypotension was reported, but the medication was discontinued and alternative agents are being considered. Development prior to the injury was described as age-appropriate, and immunizations are reportedly up to date.

Richard Adams is a 14-year-old intersex individual who presents following an acute head injury sustained when struck by a falling object during outdoor activities. Since the incident, he experienced a brief period of confusion without documented loss of consciousness; he is now alert and oriented, with no focal neurological deficits on examination. History is notable for superficial burns to the scalp and upper face incurred at the same time, with erythema and blistering consistent with a thermal mechanism; ocular surfaces are spared, and there is no evidence of inhalation injury. Skin is intact elsewhere, with no prior dermatologic disease noted. Clinical course has also been complicated by nausea and mild headache responsive to analgesics, without vomiting or seizure activity. Review of current medications is unremarkable; however, chart review documents a recent course of penicillin-class antibiotics for a respiratory infection, during which he developed diffuse pruritus and urticarial rash shortly after dosing, raising concern for a medication-related adverse reaction. No prior genetic testing is reported.

Paul Mitchell (born 09-Jan-2022) is seen in metabolic and neurology clinic for evaluation of feeding-related symptoms and motor incoordination. Since early infancy, caregivers have noticed irritability, abdominal bloating, and loose stools following ingestion of milk and other dairy products, with partial improvement on dairy restriction and use of lactose‑free formula. Growth has been appropriate to date, though there is concern about limited dietary variety due to avoidance of dairy. Neurologic history is notable for clumsiness and difficulty with coordinated movements; parents describe frequent falls, trouble with fine motor tasks such as stacking blocks, and an unsteady, wide-based gait. Development of language and social skills has otherwise progressed as expected for age. Family history is notable for a maternal uncle with long‑standing balance problems requiring use of a cane in adulthood, and a paternal grandmother with “sensitive stomach” and chronic intolerance to milk. Additional history includes a father with early-onset hypertension and a maternal grandfather with psoriasis. No prior genetic testing has been performed.

Donna Adams is a 15-year-old girl with a history notable for recurrent generalized seizure-like episodes beginning in mid-childhood, occasionally associated with brief postictal confusion but no persistent focal deficits. Events have occurred both during intercurrent illnesses and at baseline health, with some episodes preceded by nausea and malaise. Clinical concerns also include recurrent disturbances in acid–base balance, with documented episodes of metabolic acidosis during acute decompensations, sometimes requiring emergency department evaluation and intravenous fluids. Between episodes, she is generally well, with no reported developmental regression and attending mainstream school. There is no history of toxin exposure or significant head trauma. Family history is notable for a maternal uncle with epilepsy diagnosed in adolescence and treated with antiseizure medication, and a paternal grandmother with type 2 diabetes and hypertension. A paternal cousin reportedly required surgery for congenital heart disease in infancy. Prior genetic testing has included a targeted epilepsy gene panel, which was nondiagnostic, showing no clearly pathogenic or likely pathogenic variants.

Robert Perez is a 10-year-old boy with a history notable for recurrent unprovoked seizures beginning in early childhood, described as generalized convulsive episodes with postictal confusion and occasional tongue biting. Parents report intermittent episodes of lethargy and poor appetite, and prior evaluations have documented persistently abnormal laboratory values suggesting an underlying disturbance in metabolic homeostasis, though a specific diagnosis has not yet been established. Between seizures he is generally well, with no reported developmental regression. There is no history of significant head trauma, CNS infection, or perinatal complications. Family history is notable for a maternal uncle with epilepsy beginning in adolescence, and a paternal cousin who required long-term treatment for an unspecified metabolic disorder in childhood. Additionally, Robert’s maternal grandmother has long-standing type 2 diabetes and hypertension, and his father underwent coronary stenting in his early 40s. No known consanguinity is reported. He is followed by neurology and metabolic specialists, and the family is seeking further evaluation to clarify the etiology of his seizures and biochemical abnormalities.

Anthony Campbell (born 22 Feb 2007, intersex) is seen for longstanding neurologic and metabolic concerns. Since early childhood, history is notable for progressive difficulty with coordinated movements, described as clumsiness, wide‑based gait, and impaired fine motor skills affecting handwriting and utensil use. Parents report intermittent tremulousness when reaching for objects and frequent falls, without clear precipitating trauma. School notes describe slowed performance on tasks requiring motor planning, though cognitive abilities are otherwise age appropriate. Clinical concerns also include episodes of unexplained lethargy and light sensitivity, with occasional nausea after prolonged outdoor activity; diet is somewhat self‑restricted due to aversion to certain protein‑rich foods. Growth has tracked along the lower percentiles but remains stable. Family history is significant for a maternal uncle with an undiagnosed movement disorder beginning in adolescence and progressive gait imbalance. A paternal grandfather reportedly had type 2 diabetes and ischemic heart disease in his 60s, and a maternal grandmother has hypothyroidism. No prior genetic testing has been documented.

Mark Brown (born 2013-03-20, intersex) is seen for ongoing neurologic and metabolic concerns. Since early childhood, history is notable for intermittent episodes of lethargy, poor feeding during intercurrent illness, and laboratory evidence of disordered amino acid metabolism consistent with a defect in phenylalanine processing. Parents report that when dietary intake is not carefully monitored, Mark becomes irritable, has difficulty concentrating, and occasionally complains of headaches and nausea. Neurologic history includes periods of increased muscle tone in the neonatal period, with early life stiffness and jitteriness that gradually improved but left mild residual clumsiness and fine motor incoordination. There have been no documented seizures, but teachers have raised concerns about variable attention and slowed processing during more cognitively demanding tasks.  

Family history is notable for a maternal uncle with type 1 diabetes diagnosed in adolescence and a paternal grandmother with late-onset breast cancer. A younger sibling has well-controlled asthma. Parents deny known consanguinity, and there is no known family history of similar metabolic or neurologic symptoms.
